paragraph.docTitle:
Alkaloids with cholinesterase inhibitory activities from the bulbs of
Crinum
× amabile Donn ex Ker Gawl

Waraluck Chaichompoo a, b

subSection.paragraph:
C rinum
× amabile Donn ex Ker Gawl.
Alkaloids
Acetylcholinesterase
Butyrylcholinesterase
Molecular docking
ABSTRACT

Seven previously undescribed alkaloids, crinamabilines A–G, two non-alkaloidal compounds, crinamabidiene and 6-phenylpiperonyl alcohol, two first naturally occurring alkaloids, 3-epibuphanisine and (+)-1 β ,2 β -epoxy-epicrinine, together with nineteen known alkaloids, were isolated from the bulbs of
Crinum × amabile Donn ex Ker Gawl. Their
structures and absolute configurations were elucidated by NMR, MS and ECD spectroscopic techniques. Ungeremine displayed the most potent inhibitory activity against acetylcholinesterase (IC 50 0.21 μM), which was about 6-fold more active than the reference drug, galanthamine (IC 50 1.23 μM). Ungeremine also exhibited the strongest inhibitory activity against butyrylcholinesterase (IC 50 3.57 μM), which was comparable to galanthamine (IC 50 3.11 μM). The molecular docking studies were performed and were well in agreement with the experimental results.

The Amaryllidaceae plants are generally bulbous plants, which are widely distributed in the tropical and subtropical regions of the world ( Elgorashi, 2019 ). The family comprises more than 1600 species belonging to about 75 genera ( Christenhusz and Byng, 2016 ). The traditional uses of plants of the Amaryllidaceae family are attributed to the exclusive alkaloid chemistry ( Nair and van Staden, 2013 ). More than 500 alkaloids have been reported from various Amaryllidaceae plants with a wide range of pharmacological activities ( Rønsted et al., 2012 ). Members of the Amaryllidaceae plants are well known for their biologically active alkaloids, including galanthamine, which is currently available in the market for the treatment of Alzheimer’ s disease (AD) ( Loy and Schneider, 2006 ).

AD is a neurodegenerative disorder that represents the most common cause of human dementia ( Larson et al., 1992 ). Cholinergic neurotransmission represents the main approach to impaired cognitive function in AD and dementia patients. In the brain tissue, two cholinesterase enzymes including acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and butyrylcholinesterase (BuChE) play a crucial role in the neurotransmitters imbalance, particularly acetylcholine (ACh). These enzymes contribute to the hydrolytic degradation of ACh in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus. Accordingly, the inhibition of AChE and BuChE is considered a promising strategy for the treatment of AD ( Marucci et al., 2020 ). As part of our ongoing studies on a potential source of ChE inhibitors from Thai medicinal plants, a number of plant species have been screened for AChE and BuChE inhibitory activities. The results showed that the crude extracts of the bulbs of
C. amabile
exhibited anti-AChE and anti-BuChE potentials. Thus, we report herein the isolation and structure elucidation of seven previously undescribed alkaloids, crinamabilines A–G ( 1–7 ), two non-alkaloidal compounds, crinamabidiene ( 8 ) and 6-phenylpiperonyl alcohol ( 9 ), two first naturally occurring alkaloids, 3-epibuphanisine ( 10 ) and (+)-1 β ,2 β -epoxy-epicrinine ( 11 ), along with nineteen known alkaloids 12–30 ( Fig. 1 ). The in vitro AChE and BuChE inhibitory activities of most of the isolated compounds were assessed. The molecular docking studies were successfully performed to illustrate the bindings between the top-scoring alkaloids and the active sites of AChE and BuChE.

footnote.paragraph: * Corresponding author. Department of Food and Pharmaceutical Chemistry, Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok 10330, Thailand .

subSection.paragraph:
Based on our preliminary screening of Thai medicinal plants with cholinesterase inhibition, we found that the active EtOAc and BuOH crude extracts of the bulbs of
C. amabile
showed inhibitory activities against AChE and BuChE with IC 50 ranging from 0.2 to 1.1 μg/mL and 1.2–2.3 μg/mL, respectively. These extracts were therefore subjected to column chromatography and led to the isolation of thirty compounds. The chemical structures of the isolated compounds were elucidated and characterized by spectroscopic ( 1 H and 13 C NMR, HR-TOFMS, optical rotation and ECD spectra) data.

Compound 1 was obtained as a white amorphous solid. The HR-TOFMS (positive ion electrospray ionization, ESI + ) at m/z 288.1243 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 16 H 18 NO 4 , 288.1230) was compatible with the molecular formula C 16 H 17 NO 4 . The IR spectrum indicated the presence of hydroxy ( 3253 cm 1 ), olefinic ( 1654 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 931 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H NMR spectrum ( Table 1 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S1 S 4 ) showed the presence of two para - oriented aromatic protons as singlets at δ H 6.91 and 6.53 assignable to H-10 and H-7, respectively. The singlet signal at δ H 5.86 could be assigned to the methylenedioxy proton. Two benzylic protons appeared as two doublet resonances at δ H 4.28 and 3.74 ( J = 16.7 Hz) corresponding to H-6. The olefinic proton signals at δ H 6.40 (brd, J = 10.1 Hz) and 6.17 (ddd, J = 10.1, 5.1 and 0.7 Hz) were ascribable to H-1 and H-2, respectively. The small coupling constant (0.7 Hz) was due to the long-range W coupling between the H-2 and the H-4eq ( Frahm et al., 1981 ; Viladomat et al., 1995 ). The presence of one lowfield methine signal at δ H 4.25–4.28 was indicative of a hydroxy group located on C-3. H-4ax and H-4eq appeared at δ H 2.23 (ddd, J = 13.4, 13.4 and 4.4 Hz) and δ H 1.80, dddd, J = 13.4, 4.7, 1.3 and 0.7 Hz), respectively. The small coupling constants between H-3 (W ½ = 11.1 Hz) and both H-4ax (4.4 Hz) and H-4eq (1.3 Hz) were in agreement with the α -ethano bridge and an axial-oriented hydroxy substituent at C-3 ( Emir et al., 2016 ). The 13 C NMR and DEPT-135 data ( Table 5 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S5 S 6) showed the presence of sixteen carbon resonances attributed to five quaternary, seven methine and four methylene carbons. In addition, in the HMBC experiments ( Fig. 2 and Table S1 ), H-1 showed correlations with C-2 ( δ C 133.3), C-3 ( δ C 65.2), C-4a ( δ C 64.1), C-10a ( δ C 137.6) and C-10 b ( δ C 51.8), whereas H-2 correlated with C-4 ( δ C 33.5) and C-10 b. The H-4a ( δ H 3.39, brdd, J = 13.4 and 4.7 Hz) was connected to C-6 ( δ C 62.2), C-10a, C-11 ( δ C 81.5) and C-12 ( δ C 64.3) through three-bonds HMBC interaction. The benzylic protons at position 6 were also correlated with C-4a, C-7 ( δ C 108.3), C-10a and C- 12 in the HMBC spectrum. Moreover, the HMBC correlations between H-7 with C-6, C-9 ( δ C 148.6) and C-10a, and H-10 with C-6a ( δ C 127.4), C-8 ( δ C 148.1), and C-10 b, along with the correlation between methylenedioxy proton and C-8 and C-9, were also observed. The structural assignment for compound 1 was supported by the analysis of its NOESY spectrum ( Fig. 3 ). The H-3eq signal displayed a key interaction with H-4ax, whereas H-4eq correlated with H-4a, suggesting the equatorial-orientation of H-3. Moreover, H-4a displayed key interactions with H-6 β and H-4eq, whereas H-4ax showed a correlation with H-12 exo ( δ H 3.11, dd, J = 13.8 and 3.4 Hz). Moreover, H-6 α correlated with H-12 endo ( δ H 3.41, brdd, J = 13.8 and 7.0 Hz), and H-10 showed a correlation with H-1. The relative configuration of C-11 was also determined by the NOESY relationship with H-12 exo, which indicated an exo disposition of H-11 ( δ H 3.94, ddd, J = 7.0, 3.4 and 0.9 Hz). It should be noted that the presence of very small coupling constants or the broad signals of the H-4a, H-6, H-11 and H-12 resulted from the long-range couplings in this type of core structure ( Viladomat et al., 1995 ). As illustrated in Fig. 3 , the findings suggest that C-11 has the R configuration ( Abdel-Halim et al., 2004 ). The ECD spectral patterns of the α -ethano and β -ethano bridges have been reported ( DeAngelis and Wildman, 1969 ; Wagner et al., 1996 ; Bastida et al., 2006 ; Chen et al., 2011 ; Chaichompoo et al., 2020 ). A comparison was made between the ECD spectra of vittatine, the α -ethano oriented alkaloid, which showed a negative Cotton effect around 240 nm and a positive Cotton effect around 290 nm , and the β -ethano oriented alkaloid, crinine, which showed Cotton effects at the two wavelengths with opposite signs ( Wagner et al., 1996 ; Abdel-Halim et al., 2004 ). The experimental ECD spectrum of compound 1 ( Fig. 4 ) showed a negative Cotton effect at 244 nm (Δ ε 34.5) and a positive Cotton effect at 294 nm (Δ ε + 31.3), which was in agreement with the haemanthamine-type alkaloid, haemanthamine ( DeAngelis and Wildman, 1969 ). These observations suggest that the absolute configuration of compound 1 was 3 S ,4a S ,5 R ,10bR,11 R as presented in Fig. 1 . On the basis of these data, the structure of compound 1 was established as shown and was named crinamabiline A.

Compound 2 was isolated as a white amorphous solid and was assigned a molecular formula of C 19 H 21 NO 6 as deduced by HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) at m/z 360.1445 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 19 H 22 NO 6 , 360.1441). The IR spectrum showed absorption bands of hydroxy (3400

cm 1 ), acetoxy ( 1735 cm 1 ), olefinic ( 1644 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 933 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of compound 2 ( Tables 1 and 5 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S17 S21) were similar to those of compound 1 . The main differences were the presence of an additional singlet methoxy group ( δ H 3.38) in the pseudoaxial orientation at the 3-position that induced a shielding effect on H-3eq, which was confirmed by the HMBC correlation of the methoxy group with C-3 ( δ C 78.3) (see Fig. 2 and Table S1 ). The small coupling constant between H-3eq ( δ H 4.04–4.07, m, W ½ = 11.8 Hz) and both H-4ax ( δ H 2.06–2.12) and H-4eq ( δ H 1.96, dddd, J = 13.0, 5.4, 4.0 and 1.3 Hz) confirmed the orientation of the α -ethano bridge and an axial-oriented methoxy substituent at C-3 ( Emir et al., 2016 ). In addition, the NOE difference experiments were also confirmed to be similar to those of the NOESY experiments. Thus, irradiation at the H-3 frequency of compound 2 resulted in key NOE enhancement of the H-4ax signal (Fig. S165). In addition, the presence of one highly deshielded benzylic proton as a singlet signal at δ H 6.14 was indicative of an acetoxy group located on C-6. The presence of this acetoxy group was supported by the carbonyl resonance at δ C 172.3 in the 13 C NMR spectra and the HMBC correlations of H-6 with carbonyl and methyl ( δ C 20.9) carbon resonances. The β -orientation of the C-6 acetoxy group was established from the NOESY correlation ( Fig. 3 ) between H-6 and H-12 endo ( δ H 3.50, brdd, J = 13.9 and 7.0 Hz) confirmed the α -orientation of H-6. The absolute configuration of this alkaloid was determined from the ECD experiments in analogy to compound 1 ( Fig. 4 ) that exhibited a similar negative Cotton effect at 245 nm (Δ ε 35.0) and a positive Cotton effect at 290 nm (Δ ε + 35.6). The stereochemistry of the substituents at C-3 and C-6, which does not affect the signs of the ECD spectrum, is consistent with the previous report ( DeAngelis and Wildman, 1969 ). The absolute configuration of 2 was thus determined as 3 S , 4a S ,5 R ,6 S ,10bR,11 R . Based on these data, the structure of compound 2 was established and was named crinamabiline B.

subSection.paragraph: Compound 3 was obtained as a white amorphous solid, which was deduced to have a molecular formula of C 19 H 21 NO 6 by the HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) at m/z 360.1439 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 19 H 22 NO 6 , 360.1441). The IR spectrum displayed absorption bands of hydroxy ( 3399 cm 1 ), acetoxy ( 1738 cm 1 ), olefinic ( 1642 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 928 cm 1 ) functionalities. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of compound 3 ( Tables 1 and 5 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S32 S36) showed closely similar spectral features to those of compound 2 . The significant difference was the acetoxy signal ( δ H 2.20 and δ C 171.9) in the α -orientation, which is evident from the NOESY correlation of the benzylic proton H-6 ( δ H 6.63) and H-4a ( δ H 3.49, brdd, J = 13.0 and 3.7 Hz) (see Fig. 3 ). It should be mentioned that the relatively more down-field signal of H-6 β ( δ H 6.63) of compound 3 than that of the H-6 α ( δ H 6.14) of compound 2 was consistent with that reported previously ( Viladomat et al., 1996 ). Furthermore, the α -oriented OAc group in compound 3 caused considerable downfield shift (0.47 ppm) of the H-12 endo and upfield shift (0.21 ppm) of the H-12 exo resonances compared with compound 1 . The absolute configuration of this compound was also determined from the ECD experiments that exhibited a similar negative Cotton effect at 250 nm (Δ ε 52.3) and a positive Cotton effect at 280 nm (Δ ε + 37.0) to those of compound 2 . The absolute configuration of 3 was confirmed as 3 S ,4a S ,5 R ,6 R ,10bR,11 R . Therefore, the structure of compound 3 was established as shown and this compound was named crinamabiline C.

Compound 4 was obtained as a white amorphous solid. The HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) at m/z 332.1494 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 18 H 22 NO 5 , 332.1492) was compatible with the molecular formula C 18 H 21 NO 5 . The IR spectrum exhibited absorption bands of hydroxy ( 3424 cm 1 ), olefinic ( 1664 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 931 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of compound 4 ( Tables 2 and 5 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S48 S53) were similar to those of compound 2 . The first significant difference was the presence of a pseudoequatorial methoxy proton ( δ H 3.38, s). The HMBC correlation between this methoxy proton with a carbon resonance at δ C 78.4 confirmed that the location of the methoxy group was C-3 (see Fig. 2 and Table S2 ). The magnitude of coupling constants between H-3ax ( δ H 4.00–4.05, m, W ½ = 20.8 Hz) and both H-4ax ( δ H 2.09, ddd, J = 13.7, 10.6 and 9.7 Hz) and H-4eq ( δ H 1.91, dddd, J = 13.7, 5.6, 3.0 and 0.7 Hz) were in agreement with the α -ethano bridge and an equatorial-oriented methoxy substituent at C-3. The difference of the large coupling constant (10.6 Hz) between H-3ax and H-4ax in compound 4 and between H-3eq and H-4ax (W ½ of H-3 was 11.8 Hz) in compound 2 was noted. The equatorial-orientation of the C-3 methoxy group was also established from the NOESY interaction of H-3 with H-4a ( δ H 3.36, brdd, J = 9.7 and 3.0 Hz) and correlations of H-4a with H-3 and H-4eq confirmed the axial-orientation of H-3 ( Fig. 3 ). In addition, the NOE difference experiments also confirmed the orientation of H-3. Thus, irradiation at the H-3 frequency of compound 4 resulted in key NOE enhancements of the H-4a and H-4eq signals (Fig. S167). The second main difference was the presence of a singlet proton at δ H 3.57 assignable to the pseudoaxial methoxy proton at C-6. This assignment was confirmed by the HMBC correlation of the 6-methoxy proton with C-6 ( δ C 97.8). Moreover, the NOESY relationship between H-6 ( δ H 4.47) and H-12 endo ( δ H 3.31, brdd, J = 14.1 and 7.0 Hz) indicated the α -orientation for H-6. The absolute configuration of 4 was also confirmed by the ECD experiments that exhibited a similar negative Cotton effect at 245 nm (Δ ε 16.7) and a positive Cotton effect at 292 nm (Δ ε + 18.6) to those of compound 2 . The absolute configuration of 4 was therefore elucidated as 3 R ,4a S ,5 R ,6 S ,10bR,11 R and this compound was named crinamabiline D.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 3. Key NOESY correlations of compounds 1–8 , 10 and 11 .

subSection.paragraph: Compound 5 was obtained as a white amorphous solid. The molecular formula of compound 5 was determined to be C 18 H 21 NO 5 based on the HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) at m/z 332.1496 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 18 H 22 NO 5 , 332.1492). The IR spectrum indicated the presence of hydroxy ( 3419 cm 1 ), olefinic ( 1652 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 936 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of 5 ( Tables 2 and 5 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S65 S70) closely resembled those of 4 . The significant difference was the C-6 methoxy group was in the α -orientation, which was established by the NOESY experiment. The NOESY correlation between H-6 ( δ H 5.06) and H-4a ( δ H 3.29–3.32) confirmed the β -orientation of H-6 (see Fig. 3 ). It is noteworthy that the methoxy substituent exerted a similar effect to that of the acetoxy substituent in compound 3 . The α -oriented 6-OMe group in compound 5 caused a downfield shift (0.52 ppm) of the H-12 endo and an upfield shift (0.37 ppm) of the H-12 exo resonances compared with the β -oriented 6-OMe of compound 4 . The absolute configuration of this alkaloid was confirmed from the ECD experiments analogous to compound 4 with a similar negative Cotton effect at 245 nm (Δ ε 41.7) and a positive Cotton effect at 292 nm (Δ ε + 46.5). The absolute configuration of 5 was established as 3 R ,4a S ,5 R ,6 R ,10bR,11 R . On the basis of these data, the structure of compound 5 was elucidated as shown and was named crinamabiline E.

Compound 6 was isolated as a white amorphous solid. The HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) at m/z 402.1547 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 21 H 24 NO 7 , 402.1547) was compatible with the molecular formula C 21 H 23 NO 7 . The IR spectrum showed absorption bands of acetoxy ( 1738 cm 1 ), olefinic ( 1622 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 931 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of compound 6 ( Tables 2 and 5 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S81 S85) were similar to those of compound 4 . The significant difference was the presence of a highly deshielded benzylic proton as a singlet at δ H 6.15 and a carbon resonance at δ C 88.2, together with an acetoxy group ( δ H 2.10, and δ C 172.4 and δ C 21.7). The HMBC correlations between the benzylic proton and the acetoxy methyl proton and the carbonyl carbon resonance confirmed that the acetoxy group was located at C-6 ( Fig. 2 and Table S2 ). Another main difference was the presence of an additional acetoxy group ( δ H 2.00, and δ C 172.5 and 21.6) and this group should be placed at C-11 as evidenced by the highly deshielded methine signal at δ H 4.84–4.87. This was further supported by the HMBC interaction between the acetoxy methyl proton and H-11. Compound 6 exhibited a similar ECD spectrum as those of compound 4 with a similar negative Cotton effect at 252 nm (Δ ε 8.5) and a positive Cotton effect at 280 nm (Δ ε + 30.6), suggesting the same R -configuration at C-11. The absolute configuration of 6 was therefore concluded as 3 R ,4a S ,5 R ,6 S ,10bR,11 R . Consequently, compound 6 was elucidated as shown and was named crinamabiline F.

subSection.paragraph:
Compound 7 was obtained as a white amorphous solid. The molecular formula C 17 H 21 NO 5 was determined by the HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) at m/ z 320.1491 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 17 H 22 NO 5 , 320.1492). The IR spectrum exhibited the absorption bands of hydroxy ( 3356 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 933 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of compound 7 ( Tables 3 and 5 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S96 S101) showed most spectral patterns similar to those of compound 4 and other compounds, but some differences in spectral patterns were present. The notable difference was the absence of the olefinic proton signals at C-1 and C-2. Additionally, the presence of two coupled methylene protons at δ H 2.58 (ddd, J = 13.5, 4.8 and 2.1 Hz, H-1eq), 1.92 (ddd, J = 13.5, 12.9 and 5.2 Hz, H-1ax), 1.83 (dddd, J = 13.3, 12.9, 11.2 and 4.8 Hz, H-2ax) and 1.97 (brdddd, J = 13.3, 5.2, 4.4 and 2.1 Hz, H-2eq) indicated that compound 7 had an additional hydrogenated residue relative to those of 6-hydroxycrinamine ( 18 ) ( Viladomat et al., 1996 ), which has also been isolated from
C. amabile
in the present work. The 13 C NMR data are consistent with these observations ( Table 5 ). The 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC experiments ( Fig. 2 ) confirmed the foregoing assignments. The presence of the benzylic proton signal at δ H 4.97 suggested that a hydroxy substituent was located at position 6, which was confirmed by HMBC correlations of H-6 with C-4a ( δ C 60.4), C-7 ( δ C 108.6), C-10a ( δ C 139.7) and C-12 ( δ C 58.1) ( Fig. 2 ). The α -orientation of H-6 was confirmed by the NOESY correlation of this proton with H-12 endo . The configuration of C-11 was established by the NOESY correlations of H-11 ( δ H 4.02, brdd, J = 6.7 and 3.9 Hz) with H-1eq and H-10 ( δ H 6.64), which indicated an endo disposition of H-11. The results, illustrated in Fig. 3 , therefore, suggest that C-11 has the S configuration. The absolute configuration of this alkaloid was determined from the ECD experiment, which showed a negative Cotton effect at 246 nm (Δ ε 33.2) and a positive Cotton effect at 280 nm (Δ ε + 20.8), which is in agreement with compound 19 . As the endo disposition of H-11 does not exert a considerable effect on the ECD spectrum ( DeAngelis and Wildman, 1969 ; Abdel-Halim et al., 2004 ; Chaichompoo et al., 2020 ), the similar ECD curve of compound 7 ( Fig. 4 ) compared with those of compounds 1–6 has led to a conclusion that the absolute configuration of compound 7 is an α -ethano oriented alkaloid ( DeAngelis and Wildman, 1969 ; Wagner et al., 1996 ; Chen et al., 2011 ). The absolute configuration of 7 was elucidated as 3 R ,4a S ,5 R ,6 S ,10bR,11 S . On the basis of these findings, compound 7 was concluded as crinamabiline G.

subSection.paragraph:
Compound 8 was isolated as a white amorphous solid with a sodiated molecular ion of the HR-TOFMS at m/z 283.0947 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 15 H 16 NaO 4 , 283.0940) and the NMR data have led to the assignment of the molecular formula C 15 H 16 O 4 . The IR spectrum revealed the absorption bands of hydroxy ( 3274 cm 1 ), olefinic ( 1635 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 931 cm 1 ) groups. The 13 C NMR and DEPT-135 data ( Table 4 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S115 S116) showed the presence of fifteen carbons belonging to one methyl, six methine, three methylene and five quaternary carbons, suggesting the phenylcyclohexadiene analog ( Highet et al., 1968 ). The 1 H NMR spectrum ( Table 4 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S112 S114) showed the presence of a 1,2,4,5-tetrasubstituted aromatic ring at δ H 6.93 and 6.59, which are assigned to H-2 and H-5, respectively. The singlet signal at δ H 5.91 is assignable to the methylenedioxy proton. The occurrences of two-coupled olefinic protons at δ H 6.14 (brd, J = 9.5 Hz) and 6.01 (brdd, J = 9.5 and 3.9 Hz), together with an olefinic proton at δ H 5.78 (dddd, J = 4.6, 4.2, 1.1 and 1.0 Hz) were ascribable to H-6 ′ , H-5 ′ and H-2 ′ , respectively. The presences of one highly deshielded methine signal at δ H 4.10 (dddd, J = 6.6, 6.6, 3.9 and 1.1 Hz) and one methyl proton at δ H 3.34 (s) were indicative of a methoxy group and the correlations of 4 ′ -OCH 3 with C-4 ′ ( δ C 73.0) and H-4 ′ with H-2 ′ and H-5 ′ confirmed the location of a methoxy group at C-4 ′ . The small coupling constants of H-4 ′ with H-3 ′ ( δ H 2.59, ddd, J = 6.6, 4.6 and 4.2 Hz) and H-5 ′ were in agreement with the axial-oriented methoxy substituent at C-4 ′ . The axial-orientation of the C-4 ′ methoxy group was also established from the NOESY correlation of H-4 ′ with H-5 ′ and correlations of H-5 ′ with H-6 ′ confirmed the equatorial-orientation of H-4 ′ ( Fig. 3 ). One oxygenated methylene proton appeared as a singlet at δ H 4.45, indicating the benzylic methylene group. In the HMBC experiments ( Fig. 2 and Table S4 ), the α -H ( δ H 4.45, s) showed the correlations with C-1 ( δ C 136.6), C-6 ( δ C 136.0) and C-1 ′ ( δ C 134.0), whereas H-2 correlated with C-3 ( δ C 148.6), C-4 ( δ C 148.8), C-6 and α -C ( δ C 63.0). Moreover, the HMBC interactions between H-5 with C-1, C-3, C-4, C-6 and C-1 ′ were also observed. According to the above evidence, the structure of 8 was determined as 6-(4 ′ -methoxy-1 ′ ,5 ′ -cyclohexadienyl)piperonyl alcohol and was named crinamabidiene. The skeleton of compound
8 in
relation to those of the alkaloids isolated in this work has led to a postulate that this compound could possibly derive from the degradation of a constituent alkaloid present in
C. amabile
similar to the previous report for the degradation of other Amaryllidaceae alkaloids ( Zhan et al., 2017 ). More information is needed on whether the transformation has occurred by enzymatic or non-enzymatic means.

Compound 9 was isolated along with compound 8 . The molecular formula C 14 H 12 O 3 was deduced from the HR-TOFMS at m/z 251.0682 [M + Na] + (calcd. for C 14 H 12 NaO 3 , 251.0678). The IR spectrum revealed the absorption bands of hydroxy ( 3393 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 932 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H NMR spectra ( Table 4 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S128 S130) revealed the presence of the same piperonyl alcohol moiety as that of compound 8 . The presence of the aromatic proton signals at δ H 7.31 (m, 3H, H-3 ′ , H-4 ′ and H-5 ′ ) and δ H 7.38 (m, 2H, H-2 ′ and H-6 ′ ) has led to the conclusion that compound 9 is 6-phenylpiperonyl alcohol. In fact, this compound has been reported previously as an intermediate of chemical degradation of an alkaloid ( Ikeda et al., 1956 ). Compound 9 should therefore be obtained from compound 8 by the elimination of methanol.

caption.paragraph: 1 H NMR data (400 MHz) of compounds 8 and 9 and 13 C NMR data (100 MHz) of compound 8 in CD 3 OD ( δ in ppm, J in Hz).

subSection.paragraph:
Compound 10 was obtained as a white amorphous solid. The HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) at m/z 286.1432 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 17 H 20 NO 3 , 286.1437) was compatible with the molecular formula C 17 H 19 NO 3 . The IR spectrum indicated the presence of olefinic ( 1644 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 932 cm 1 ) groups. The 1 H NMR spectra ( Table 3 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S132 S135) showed the presence of a 1,2,4,5-tetrasubstituted aromatic ring and the methylenedioxy group, which are characteristic of the aromatic ring of the alkaloids found in this plant species. Two doublets at δ H 4.47 and 3.85 (each J = 17.0 Hz) are indicative of the unsubstituted C-6 benzylic carbon. The olefinic proton signals at δ H 6.61 (brd, J = 10.0 Hz) and 6.00 (dd, J = 10.0 and 5.2 Hz) were ascribable to H-1 and H-2, respectively. The presence of one deshielded methine signal at δ H 3.83–3.87 (m, W ½ = 20.5 Hz) and a methoxy signal at δ H 3.88 (s) was noted. The ECD experiment of 10 has thus been determined and it was found that its ECD curve exhibited opposite Cotton effects to those of compounds 1–7 with a positive Cotton effect at 244 nm (Δ ε + 24.0) and a negative Cotton effect at 294 nm (Δ ε 22.8) ( Fig. 4 ), which was in agreement with the crinine-type alkaloid ( DeAngelis and Wildman, 1969 ). The large coupling constants between H-3ax and both H-4 ( δ H 2.22 and 1.64) were in agreement with an β -ethano bridge and an equatorial-oriented methoxy substituent at C-3. The HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 2 ) confirmed the methoxy group was placed at C-3. The structural assignment for compound 10 was supported by the analysis of its NOESY spectrum ( Fig. 3 ). The NOESY experiments thus confirmed the relative configuration of compound 10 . A comparison was made between the ECD spectra of the β -ethano oriented crinine, which showed a positive Cotton effect around 240 nm and a negative Cotton effect around 290 nm , and the α -ethano oriented vittatine, which showed Cotton effects at the two wavelengths with opposite signs ( Wagner et al., 1996 ). These observations suggest that the absolute configuration of 10 is as shown in Fig. 1 . Compound 10 , epibuphanisine, has been mentioned as one of the products in the synthesis of crinine analogs ( Tang, 2017 ), but no information about this compound was provided. It should be noted that the name of the synthetic compound given by the previous work may lead to confusion since this name has already been used for compound 12 previously isolated ( Viladomat et al., 1995 ) and this compound has also been isolated from
C. amabile
in this study. We therefore suggest that the alkaloid 10 should be named 3-epibuphanisine. This compound has therefore been isolated from a natural source for the first time.

subSection.paragraph: Compound 11 was isolated as a white amorphous solid and was assigned the molecular formula C 16 H 17 NO 4 as determined from the HR-TOFMS (ESI + ) at m/z 288.1255 [M + H] + (calcd. for C 16 H 18 NO 4 , 288.1230). The IR spectrum indicated the presence of hydroxy ( 3356 cm 1 ), epoxide ( 1284 cm 1 ) and methylenedioxy ( 934 cm 1 ) moieties. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of compound 11 ( Tables 3 and 5 , the NMR spectra are in Supplementary data, Fig. S148 S153) displayed similar spectral features to those of compound 10 , except two olefinic proton signals in compound 10 were replaced by two oxygenated methine signals at δ H 3.89 (d, J = 3.5 Hz) and δ H 3.26 (brdd, J = 3.5 and 2.7 Hz) assignable to H-1 and H-2, respectively. These NMR spectral data, together with the evidence from the HR-TOFMS, indicate that the double bond at C-1 and C-2 is epoxidized. The conformation of the epoxide ring was assigned from the small coupling constants of H-1 with H-2 ( J = 3.5 Hz) and H-2 with H-3 ( J = 2.7 Hz). In addition, a deshielded methine proton at δ H 4.37–4.43 (m, W ½ = 21.0 Hz) was observed. The HMBC correlations from H-2 and H-4a to C-3 ( δ C 65.9) unambiguously placed the hydroxy group at C-3 ( Fig. 2 and Table S3 ). The NOESY correlation (see Fig. 3 ) between H-3 and H-4a ( δ H 3.40, brdd, J = 10.5 and 6.1 Hz) was in agreement with an equatorial-oriented hydroxy substituent at C-3. Comparison of the 1 H NMR spectral features with those of flexinine ( 21 ) ( Pham et al., 1998 ), which has been isolated from this plant species in the present work, reveals that they closely resemble; the notable difference being the small W ½ value (9.1 Hz) of compound 21 that indicates the equatorial-orientation of H-3. The absolute configuration of this alkaloid was determined from the ECD experiments ( Fig. 4 ). As expected, the ECD curve of compound 11 exhibited a similar positive Cotton effect at 249 nm (Δ ε + 31.5) and a negative Cotton effect at 279 nm (Δ ε 9.1) to those of compound 10 . Compound 11 has previously been reported as a synthetic compound, (+)-1 β ,2 β -epoxy-epicrinine ( Bru and Guillou, 2006 ; Zuo et al., 2017 ) and it has therefore been first reported from a natural source in this study.

In the previous reports, a variety of genera in the Amaryllidaceae family including
Galanthus
,
Narcissus
,
Rhodophiala
,
Zephyranthes
and
Crinum
revealed the different structural types of alkaloids. The members of galanthamine-, lycorine- and haemanthamine-type alkaloids are the most abundant Amaryllidaceae plants, which have superior AChE inhibitory activities, especially, an AChEI galanthamine was approved by the FDA for treatment of AD revealing possibilities for structural modification or semi-synthesis of potent AChEIs. Alkaloid extracts and fractions of about 100 species of 20 genera resulted in more than 200 Amaryllidaceae alkaloids that have been studied for their in vitro AChE inhibitory activity. Some of these alkaloids have been studied in silico to study the interactions between Amaryllidaceae alkaloids and the AChE enzyme ( Torras-Claveria et al., 2013 ; Cortes et al., 2017 ; Berkov et al., 2021 ). For example, compounds 17–20 , 22 , 24 , 25 , 27–30 have been reported for their AChE inhibitory activity evaluation ( Elgorashi et al., 2004 ; Nair et al., 2011 ; Cahlíkova´et al., 2013; Tallini et al., 2018 ). Thus, the Amaryllidaceae alkaloids prompt the interest of researchers as promising compounds that deserve further in vitro and in vivo study to reveal new AD drugs.

In this study, most of the isolated compounds were evaluated for their AChE and BuChE inhibitory activities by the method described previously by our group (Chaichompoo et al., 2021) and the results are shown in Table 6 . Galanthamine, the well-known AChE and BuChE inhibitor, was used as the reference drug. The alkaloid ungeremine (2 9 ) exhibited the strongest inhibitory activity against AChE, with the IC 50 values of 0.21 μM, which was about 6-fold more active than galanthamine (IC 50 1.23 μM), followed by compound 19 , which showed similar inhibitory activity (IC 50 1.86 μM) to that of galanthamine. Compounds 16 and 28 showed high inhibitory activities with the IC 50 values of 6.41 and 7.08 μM, followed by compounds 7 , 10 , 12 , 15 , 18 , 20 and 21 and 23–27 , which exhibited moderate to weak AChE inhibitory activity with the IC 50 values ranging from 16.76 to 99.51 μM. In addition, alkaloid 29 also displayed the highest BuChE inhibitory activity among the tested alkaloids, with the IC 50 value of 3.57 μM, which was slightly less active than galanthamine (IC 50 3.11 μM). Furthermore, compounds 10 , 12 , 15 , 16 , 18–21 , 23, 24 and 26 showed good to low degrees of BuChE inhibitory activity with IC 50 values of 9.31–247.57 μM, whereas compounds 7 , 25 , 27 and 28 were inactive to the anti-BuChE assay. The tested compounds included two types of alkaloids, the crinane- and lycorine-type alkaloids ( Tram et al., 2002 ). As the number of each member of the compounds and the structural diversity of each type of the alkaloids are somewhat limited, a detailed structure–anti-ChE activity relationship (SAR) study could not be concluded. However, a preliminary SAR study revealed that, for the crinane-type alkaloids, the presence of the 6-hydroxy group seemed to enhance both AChE and BuChE inhibitory activities. Comparing the structures of 6-hydroxycrinamine ( 19 ) with that of galanthamine, the two compounds have comparable sizes. However, the presence of the 6-hydroxy group might contribute to its high AChE inhibitory activity since crinamine ( 18 ) was only approximately 18-folds less active than 19 . Moreover, the α -hydroxyamino function in 19 might also exist in the form of the open-ring amino aldehyde function under the test condition ( King et al., 1965 ; Jin and Xu, 2013 ) and might contribute to the high activity of 19 . However, further study is required to verify this postulate. For the lycorine-type alkaloids, the high potency of compound 29 was attributed to the presence of the ring C aromatic connected to the quaternary ammonium functionality, which is important for ChE inhibitory activities. For comparison with galanthamine, the presence of a nitrogen atom connected to the ring C aromatic seemed to be similar to active pharmacophores to those of
29 in
ChE inhibitory activities ( Katoch et al., 2013 ; Pinho et al., 2013 ). The observation was confirmed by molecular docking results.

subSection.paragraph:
The binding interaction of the alkaloid
29 in
the active site of AChE and BuChE has been studied. A molecular docking study was performed using Autodock 4.2 software to investigate the binding affinity of alkaloid 29 against AChE and BuChE by docking to its binding pocket. The relevance of the docking parameters was verified by re-docking galanthamine and tacrine to their binding sites in AChE and BuChE, respectively. The docking models of the original drugs were well aligned with their crystal structures, indicating that the setting parameters were appropriate for this study ( Fig. 5A and D ). The binding interaction, binding energy (BE, kcal/mol) and % conformation (%C) of alkaloid 29 and galantamine to the target proteins are summarized in Table S5 . The docking results suggested that alkaloid 29 has a better binding affinity to AChE than galanthamine and is equally proportional at BuChE. The strong binding interaction with key residues in the receptor binding domain was also considered as criteria in determining the potential inhibitor. Alkaloid 29 showed good binding affinity values of 8.26 kcal/ mol with a high %C of 88.5. Fig. 5C shows that compound 29 was well occupied in the active gorge of AChE at a different subsite from that of galanthamine. It was able to form two hydrogen bonds at the acyl pocket with R296 (distance of 1.75 Å) and S293 (distance of 2.11 Å) and two pi-pi interactions with Y124 and W286 at the peripheral anionic site (distances of 5.81, 5.67 Å for Y124 and 5.22 and 5.38 Å for W286), while two hydrogen bonds with the oxygen anion cavity G120 (distance of 2.84 Å) and the anionic site E202 (distance of 1.73 Å) and a pi-alkyl interaction of the oxygen anion cavity G121 (distance of 3.92 Å) were found for the galanthamine ( Fig. 5B ). It can be seen that the alkaloid 29 is not only more hydrophobic to AChE, but also has shorter hydrogen bonding distances. Therefore, it could bind to AChE better than galanthamine, which is consistent with the experimental IC 50 value. Furthermore, when compound 29 was considered in the BuChE binding pocket, it was found to bind at the same subsite as galanthamine. This alkaloid was stabilized by two pi-pi interactions with W82 (5.34 and 4.99 Å) and two hydrogen bonds with Y128 and D70 (distances of 1.80 and 2.05 Å, respectively) ( Fig. 5F ). It has a proportional binding affinity to the BuChE binding pocket as galanthamine, which forms two hydrogen bonds with the catalytic triad residue Y440 (1.86 and 1.91 Å) and two pi-pi interactions with the catalytic anionic site W82 (3.68 and 4.36 Å) ( Fig. 5E ). This is likewise the IC 50 values found in the experiment.

In conclusion, seven undescribed alkaloids ( 1–7 ), two undescribed analogs ( 8 and 9 ) and two first naturally occurring alkaloids ( 10 and 11 ), together with nineteen known alkaloids ( 12–30 ), have been isolated from
C. amabile
bulbs. Compound 29 exhibited the most potent acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitory activity, which was about 6-fold more active than galanthamine, the reference drug. Molecular docking studies are well in agreement with the experimental results. The alkaloid 29 may serve as a lead compound for anti-AChE drug development.

subSection.paragraph:
The bulbs of
Crinum × amabile Donn ex Ker Gawl. (Amaryllidaceae)
were collected from Bang Kruai District , Nonthaburi Province , Thailand (13 ◦ 80 ′ 35.7 ′′ N, 100 ◦ 41 ′ 77.4 ′′ E) in
January 2020
and the plant species was identified by Assoc. Prof. Nopporn Dumrongsiri , Ramkhamhaeng University. A voucher specimen is deposited at the Faculty of Science , Ramkhamhaeng University , Thailand ( Apichart Suksamrarn, No. 103)
.

The fresh bulbs of
C. × amabile
( 1.5 kg ) were minced and macerated with MeOH (5 × 20 L) at room temperature for 72 h in each extraction. The filtered solution was evaporated in vacuo to yield the crude MeOH extract ( 50.5 g ). The MeOH extract was suspended in 1 L distilled water and sequentially partitioned with n -hexane, EtOAc, and n -BuOH (3 × 1 L for each solvent) to give the hexane ( 0.8 g ), EtOAc (3.0 g) and butanol (36.0 g) extracts, respectively. The EtOAc and butanol extracts gave a positive test to Dragendorff’ s reagent.

heading.emphasis: 4.3.1. Isolation of the compounds from the EtOAc extract

subSection.paragraph: The crude EtOAc extract ( 2.9 g ) was fractionated by column chromatography using a gradient solvent system of CH 2 Cl 2 , CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH, and MeOH with increasing amounts of the more polar solvent. The eluates were examined by TLC and five combined fractions (A1–A5) were obtained. Fraction A1 ( 232.8 mg ) was subjected to column chromatography eluting with an isocratic condition of CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:2, v/v) to give compound 6 ( 2.4 mg ). Fraction A2 ( 1.4 g ) was column chromatographed using CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:3, v/v) as eluent to provide three subfractions (A2.1–A2.3). Subfraction A2.1 ( 86.7 mg ) was chromatographed on a silica gel column eluting with hexane–EtOAc (5:95, v/v) to yield compound 22 ( 1.6 mg ). Subfraction A2.2 ( 198.1 mg ) was further subjected to column chromatography using hexane– CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (20:80:4, v/v) as eluent to yield compounds 10 (1.0 mg) and 12 ( 2.2 mg ). Subfraction A2.3 (1.0 g) was chromatographed on silica gel column eluting with hexane– CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (20:80:5, v/v) to provide compound 20 ( 16.4 mg ). Fraction A3 ( 165.5 mg ) was subjected to column chromatography (column diameter 1 cm , with a 20 cm height of the packing material) eluting with a gradient solvent system of CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:2–100:5, v/v) to yield compounds 2 ( 1.1 mg ) and 3 ( 1.4 mg ). Fraction A4 (1.0 g) was further chromatographed by silica gel column eluting with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:4, v/v, with ca 0.5 mL volume for each fraction) to give compounds 18 ( 11.4 mg ) and 24 ( 4.5 mg ). Compound 28 (4.0 mg) was obtained after purification of fraction A5 ( 66.2 mg ) by silica column chromatography using CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:8, v/v) as eluent.

heading.emphasis: 4.3.2. Isolation of the compounds from the BuOH extract

subSection.paragraph: The crude BuOH extract (29.0 g) was fractionated by column chromatography using a gradient solvent system of CH 2 Cl 2 , CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH, and MeOH with increasing amounts of the more polar solvent. The eluates were examined by TLC and seven combined fractions (B1–B7) were obtained. Fraction B1 ( 12.7 mg ) was subjected to column chromatography eluting with a gradient solvent system of CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:2–100:4, v/v) to yield compounds 8 (1.0 mg), 9 ( 0.2 mg ) and 15 (5.0 mg). Fraction B2 ( 16.6 mg ) was repeatedly chromatographed on a silica gel column in a similar manner to that employed for the isolation of compound 2 from compound 3 , with hexane– CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (20:80:6, v/v) as eluent, to afford compounds 4 ( 0.8 mg ), 5 ( 0.5 mg ) and 23 ( 1.3 mg ). Fraction B3 ( 186.9 mg ) was further separated by silica column chromatography, using a gradient solvent system of CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:6–100:8, v/v) to provide compounds 11 ( 1.9 mg ), 16 ( 12.5 mg ), 19 ( 4.3 mg ) and 26 ( 10.5 mg ). Fraction B4 ( 8.4 g ) was chromatographed on silica column eluting with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:10, v/v) to give compounds 21 ( 1.4 mg ), 25 (130.0 mg), 27 ( 20.3 mg ) and 30 ( 0.8 mg ). Fraction B5 (144.0 mg) was similarly chromatographed eluting with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:12, v/v) to give compound 7 ( 22.5 mg ). Reversed-phase column chromatography of fraction B6 ( 78.7 mg ) using RP-18 column, with MeOH–H 2 O (6:4, v/v) as eluting solvent, furnished compounds 1 ( 1.5 mg ), 13 ( 0.8 mg ), 14 ( 0.8 mg ) and 17 ( 3.2 mg ). Column chromatography of fraction B7 ( 167.8 mg ) eluting with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (100:30, v/v) afforded compound 29 (5.0 mg).

The molecular docking technique was applied to study the binding orientation and affinity of the alkaloid 29 from the bulbs of
Crinum × amabile
toward the binding gorge of AChE and BuChE enzymes using Autodock 4.2 ( Morris et al., 1998 ). The compound was created with the program ACD Lab and then optimized by Hartree-Fock level calculations with the 6-31G* basis set using the GAUSSIAN09 package ( Frisch et al., 2010 ). The 3D protein structures of the human AChE and human BuChE enzymes were obtained from the Protein Data Bank with PDB IDs: 4EY6 and 4BDS, respectively. Galanthamine, used as a control molecule, was re-docked into the AChE binding site to determine the appropriate binding parameters for docking. Proteins were processed using AutoDock Tools ( Morris et al., 2009 ) to remove all water molecules and generate all hydrogen atoms of the molecule. Nonpolar hydrogen atoms and lone pairs were then merged and Gasteiger partial charges were assigned to each atom. A grid box of 80 × 80 × 80 points with a spacing of 0.375 Å was positioned at the center of the active site gorge. The protein molecule was kept rigid while the ligand was flexible. The autogrid4 parameter was used to attain grid maps. Furthermore, autodock4 was performed using Lamarckian genetic algorithms to obtain the best docking conformation. For each docking experiment, 250 independent docking runs were performed. The conformations were selected based on the lowest binding energy in the cluster with the most %conformations (see Table S5 ). They were then compared to their experimental IC 50 values to confirm relative accuracy. Analysis and visualization of the docking results were done using the BIOVIA Discovery studio visualizer (BIOVIA, Dassault Syst`emes, 2019).
